title: R44484
content: President Obama nominated Judge Merrick Garland of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit to fill the Supreme Court vacancy left by Justice Antonin Scalia's death. Judge Garland has served on the D.C. Circuit since 1997 and has presided over numerous cases covering a wide range of legal topics. This report summarizes over 350 cases where Judge Garland authored opinions, providing insight into his judicial approach. It excludes cases where he did not write an opinion or was part of a panel issuing a per curiam opinion. The report summarizes over 350 cases where Judge Garland authored opinions, categorizing them into two tables based on his role in the reviewing court. Cases are listed in reverse chronological order with key rulings described. Opinions are categorized into 19 legal subject areas, including civil rights, criminal law, and environmental law. Judge Garland has adjudicated cases in various legal subject areas, including federal courts, First Amendment issues, government information, health care, international law, labor law, national security, separation of powers, tax law, and transportation. The list is not exhaustive but highlights the most frequently addressed topics in his cases. Some cases involve challenges from wartime detainees at Guantanamo Bay. The legal subject areas of cases adjudicated by Judge Garland include national security, separation of powers, and administrative law, with some cases involving challenges from wartime detainees at Guantanamo Bay. The categorizations in this report may not fully capture all legal issues raised in judicial opinions authored by Judge Garland. The cases adjudicated by Judge Garland cover national security, separation of powers, and administrative law, including challenges from Guantanamo Bay detainees. The methodology for compiling these cases involved searching for majority, concurring, and dissenting opinions authored by Judge Garland in the District of Columbia Circuit database on Lexis. In cases adjudicated by Judge Garland, a methodology involving searching for majority, concurring, and dissenting opinions authored by him in the District of Columbia Circuit database on Lexis was used. This resulted in the identification of 355 instances where Judge Garland is credited as an author of a judicial opinion. Judge Garland is credited as an author of a judicial opinion in 355 instances before the D.C. Circuit or the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia.
